Topic.Title: Long term holders of IBM should welcome a priced drop...

Message.Msg: AAPL went from over 700 to under 400... that's a 'crash' IBM going from 215 to 200 is nowhere near the percentage drop, but its still a crash, according to you, why do I even bother feeding the troll?

In the early 90's one guy who considered himself the sharpest pencil in the market assured me IBM was doomed to go extinct just as the dinosaurs as you've suggested. I'll bet he's having crow for dinner these days.

Correct spelling is Arbour Place stupid. I wouldn't own this POS if it were free. You two stooges get giddy over a $10.00 pop to below where it was just 2 weeks ago. You are the pathetic ones. BTW, what is the 52 week high ? LOL.

Message.Title: I Don't Mind People Calling IBM a Dinosaur...
Message.Msg: Dinosaurs were Huge Dominating Creatures, that weren't defeated by nature or evolution, it took an unusual event, i.e. a meteor strike, that killed off nearly every species on the planet, not just the dinosaurs. IBM does 3 billion in revenue ever QUARTER, what other business is going to take over, or outcompete with them? Hewlett Packard? Oracle? (that bought Sun). They have the top engineers, produce the most patents, they're not afraid to change with the times, they're leaders, not followers. There's a reason this stock recently hit an ALL TIME HIGH, and will again, its because the analysts and money managers have to make decisions in the real world, and IBM is a DINOSAUR TO BE RECKONED WITH AND RESPECTED

Message.Title: BELOW $190.00 On The Way. Nothing To Drive The SP.
Message.Msg: Dead cat bounce is O V E R.

Message.Title: A Boy and His Atom
Message.Msg: It was a guy by the name of John Kelly who in 1962 programmed an IBM 720 to sing Daisey. Stanley kubrick then had HAL sing Daisey just before it shut itself down, committing machine sewer side. Someday IBM's Copper Boy will show up in a movie. Unless the atomic men take over first.
NEXT LETTER H I A B L M

I totally agree with you. Your observation is unpopular in today's challenging employment environment in the US, but it is nevertheless true. The way I see it, IBM did what it had to do to retain a significant US presence. As you stated, otherwise it would have really diminished as a company. As to the contract employees, this won't hurt customers. Line employees are fully capable of making up any gap. Look, I've been in consulting and know that line employees can find an extra few hours a week...as opposed to being letter of the law obstinate about getting somebody else to do it. Lastly, I am betting on IBM being strong and robust in the future, especially once wages and pricing becomes more normalized in the globalized economy. North America will benefit, while simultaneously so will emerging market employees for IBM. It isn't a zero sum game forever, like many people believe.

Skipped second round. Watching the bounce, makes more sense to buy the next pull back than to short the bounce. This "bounce" from the post ER drop, has turned into more than a bounce. So to the poster who said I was wrong, you were right.

Topic.Title: I Don't Mind People Calling IBM a Dinosaur...

Message.Msg: Name calling by those who have fantasies that they can predict the future, means nothing. I would rather own a dino that has grown for over 100 years than a fly by night that is traded by reflexive, knee jerk, absorbers of the daily noise.

Message.Title: When is value in this economy?
Message.Msg: there is no growth and many countries in recession...I expect many companies to guide lower for the next year

Topic.Title: I Don't Mind People Calling IBM a Dinosaur...

Message.Msg: Always chuckle every time I see the comparison of IBM to a dino. 100 years old and still growing.

Message.Msg: wont matter.....Uncle BEn will print them some money
